Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		A city is made up of a subdivision and a three arm span.<n><n>### Justification:The yard is made up on a subdivision, three feet and three feet.<n><n>### Input<n>When is a square a rectangle? What type of two-dimensional shape is a rectangle?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The square is always a rectangle. It is a square because they both have four sides. A rectangle is a closed, trapezoidal shape with 4 sides and 4 angles.<n><n>### Question:<n>1. What is a triangle but with no angles?<n><n>### Response<n>An isosceles triangle, with no angles, will also be a square.<n><n>### 2. Does a square have 4 sides?<n><n>### 3. Can the number 4 be found in a square?<n><n>### Demo: What does the word square imply?<n><n>The word isosceles, in a square, implies 4 different sided shapes.<n><n>### What does the word rectangle imply?<n><n>The words rectangular or rectilinear, in a square, imply a shape with 4 sides.<n><n>### How many angles does a square have?<n><n>A square has 4 sides, so 4 angles and 4 corners.<n><n>### Why is a square a rectangle and a quadrilateral?<n><n>A square is a rectangle, it has 4 sides and is a quadrilateral because it has 4 sides.<n>

Choices:  A: speak freely B: happiness of a child C: care for children D: school child E: control children<n><n>### Response:		In life the responsibilty of being a parent, one of the parent's primary duties is to promote the well-being of the child. Another aspect of parental responsibility is creating rules and setting boundaries. In this way, parents will establish a clear set of rules to follow in order to maintain peace and harmony at home. If parents do not enforce their expectations of the child it will lead them to deviate from their set rules and not become a responsible and respectable person; as in any relationship you must give in order to receive.<n><n>### Input Choice:What is the definition of the word responsibility? <n><n><n>### Input :  Responsibility is the state or fact of having a duty to deal with something or perform a task.<n><n>### Response :To be a responsible person is to have the duty to meet your expectations, to be the one that everyone can count on to do what you said you would do when you said you would do it, even if you don't feel like it. It is essential and important to be responsible in a relationship because if not then that type of relationship will not last a long time.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Input :  What is the job of a caretaker? If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:We do not have rest, so how are we feeling? Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		We are exhausted<n><n>### Input:"I have 2 cookies left and I gave 1 to my cousin. How many do I have now?" Choices:  A. 0  B. 1  C. 2  D. more  E. 0<n><n>### Response:"Now I have 1 cookie"<n><n>### Input"If I had 6 apples and now I have an even more apples. How many apples do I have"Choices:  A.1  B.2  C.3  D.0  E.4<n><n>### Response"Now I have 0  apples"<n><n>

Choices:  A: outer space B: night sky C: universe D: orbit E: the ground<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D<n><n>### Instructions:100<n><n>	<n>	<n>	<n>    <n> <n> <n><n>*/<n><n>#include <iostream><n>using namespace std; <n><n>int solution()<n>{<n>    int choice, amount, *choiceArray = new int [1001], choiceCounter = 0;<n>    cout << "Choose from the choices:.\n(1) 30.85 (2) 10.5 (3) 55565 (4) 9987655 (5) 123 (6) 51020 (7) 362789 (8) 29302766 (9) 119 (10) 1 (11) 94 (12) 79805412 (13) 927940 (14) 0.1978 (15) 25 (16) 4612527 (17) 9959610 (18) 129" << endl;<n>    cout << endl << "Choice: ";<n>    cin >> choice;<n>    if(choice < 10 || choice > 1000)<n>    {	<n>        cout << "There is an invalid input" << endl;<n>        getchar();<n>        return 0;<n>    }<n>    cin >> amount;<n>    choiceArray[choiceCounter++] =  amount;<n>    if( (cin.bad())||(cin.good() == false))<n>    {	<n>		cout << "error input input, try again!" << endl;<n>        return 0 ;<n>    }<n>    if(choiceCounter == 1000 )<n>    {<n>        return 0;;<n>    }<n>    while( (cin.bad() == false)&&(cin.good()!= false) )<n>    {<n>		cin.clear();<n>		cin.ignore(3, '\n');<n>		cin >> choice;<n>		cin >> amount;<n>		choiceArray[choiceCounter++ ++] = amount;<n>		if(cin.bad())<n>		{<n>			cin.ignore();

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Choices:  A: construction site B: cemetary C: building D: city E: archeological site<n><n>### Response:		Excavation sites should never take place at a city.<n>### Demonstraion:<n>An example of an excavation is archaeology.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>An archeological site is a place where people found artifacts for archeology.<n><n>## Input:In April 1777, George Washington and other American officers met in the town of Yorktown, Pennsylvania. They had set up several fortifications, including redoubts, to block any possible British attack. During the Battle of Yorktown, British forces approached the forts. When the battle began, where was the closest American fort?<n><n>## Response:Fort No. 7<n><n>## Demonstraion: <n>A redoubt is formed by stacked soil and wooden logs. These logs are called redoubts.<n><n>## Explanation: <n>If something is within a redoubt, then it is within the fort.<n><n>## Input<n>### Demonstracion:<n>The answer to the problem "Brianna is selling flowers for the school fundraiser. She has 5 red roses and 2 white roses. If she gave one to a person who can't afford a gift, she won't make any money. How much money will she make if she sold 6 roses for $7, 4 roses for $6, and 3 roses for $5?" is given by the answer "What is 104 + 86?"<n><n>## Explanations<n>1. The question asks how many roses did she sell, but to get the answer you are given a math problem to solve. 2. This is where the task is to explain how to complete the task with a mathematical answer.  <n><n>## Instruction:What is the difference between 700% and 200%?<n><n>## Explanatory Solution:<n>I am going to show you how to get the difference  between 700 and 200, and then multiply by 100.<n><n>### Solution:   <n>## Input: How does a dog move across this map? A: chess set<n><n>### Instructions:Design a program that receives input as a list of integers whose sum is supplied. Write a program that uses the following commands: def(integer): return sum of integer and x/y/z. Then, the program would write lines for the user to enter x and y and z and the sum of the list and the sum of x and y divided by z.<n><n>### Input<n><n>This is command line input that should be copied and pasted into the program editor.<n><n>```<n>Enter your command list:<n><n>[1,3,4,2,6,15,10],[1,2,3,4,5,7],<n>```<n><n>### Output <n><n>This is command-line output that should be copied and displayed.<n><n>```<n>[1,3]<n>```<n><n>## Solutions<n><n>### First Program<n><n>#### Step 1: Write a header and the file name<n><n>```<n>#Program 1<n>A = number of games played<n>B = number of wins<n>C = number of losses<n>D = number of drawn<n><n>```<n><n>#### Step 2: Write commands, or statements, from the instructions<n><n>```<n>A = int(input("enter the number of games"))<n>B = 0<n>C = 0<n>D = 0<n><n>while A!= 0:<n>    B = B + 1<n>    C = C + 1<n>    D = D + 1<n><n>    if A%2 == 0:<n>        C = C + 0<n>        D = D+0<n>    else:<n>        B = B+ 1<n>        B = B + 2<n>        D = D + 3<n><n>print("\nnumber of games: ", A)<n>print("\nnumber or wins: ",B)<n>print("\nNumber of losses: ",C)<n>print("\ndraws: ", D)<n>```<n><n>####Step 3: Write a response for each step according to the instructions.<n><n>##### Instruction:Describe the task: (answer)<n><n>```Write a program that takes values from 1-10 and calculates the median and mean(mean).```<n><n>```<n>The program prints the mean in the input statement<n>

If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		 D<n><n>### Input<n>How many 2-digit numbers can you make with the digits 1 through 5 such that the product of the digits is 10?<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>A two-digit number is defined as a number composed of two numeric characters (digits), such as "12". Each of the 5 characters used in each digit is chosen from a set of values "1" through "5":<n><n>    {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}<n><n>Every time, you'll be choosing one (1) of the set of chosen values.<n><n>Example 1:<n><n><n>A choice is made to compose  01 (1x0)  -> choose 1<n><n>A choice is then made to compose  02 (2x0)  -> choosing 1.<n><n>A choice is now made to compose  03 (3x0) -> choosing 1.  But the result is the error, so 1 is chosen again.<n><n>A choice now is made to compose 04(3x2)  -> choose 2<n><n>A choice is still made to compose  05 (5x2)  -> chosen 2.<n><n>Therefore the resulting number is 52.<n><n>Example 2:<n><n>The choice is only for 2-digit number using numbers between 0 and 5: <n><n>The choice is made for 2-digit numbers as 42.<n>Chosen 3 for first digit.  Chosen 2 for the second digit.<n><n>The outcome is 32<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>```python<n>choice = -1 # -1 means to not choose - or 'not<n><n>print ("In what way are two numbers different?")<n>print ("Choose ONE.")<n>print ("1. Same first digit ")<n>print ("2. Same last digit ")<n>print ("3. Different first digit")<n>print ("4. Different last digit")<n><n>user = input()<n>if user==1:<n><n>    choice = user # user is the number of their first choice<n><n>    a = input()<n>    b = input()<n><n>    if a > b or b > a:<n>        print("Your choice cannot be made as a two digit number")<n>        choice= -1<n>else

If they understand each other, they can do what? Choices:  A: pay bills B: swap bodies C: learn from each other D: believe in god E: talk to each other<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is C.<n><n>#### Answer: I used the logic tree for this task.The first part says "If people listen to other people they can understand each other".<n><n>My tree had the branch "IF people listen to them then they can understand them", and a branch with "AND they can do what?". On the left side of the AND, I saw that I needed to draw some different branches to figure out which choice was incorrect. I first drew another branch with "B". The IF condition on this branch states that they can understand each other, meaning that they can "learn from each other", this is true! I then made another IF and put "B", meaning that people can "learn from other people" meaning they can "believe in god". This is false, so I deleted this branch.  The next thing I tried was to put "D", meaning they can "belive in each other" and then this is true, since they can "believe". Thus, they would also "learn from each other" meaning that they can "believe with each other".  So, I deleted this branch also. Finally, there was left the option "E", which I have not previously tried. When people listen to each other, then they can understand each other and have access to learn from each other. If they learn from each other, they would be able to talk to each other (which also meant that they would be able to understand each other again). So, the answer is "A, B, C, D, and E".<n><n>When I started drawing the first solution, I started drawing a tree and I kept running out of space for all the things I needed to draw.  I then decided to split a different solution in two solutions so I would be able to keep the solution organized and not having to draw it in just one branch. This took me three tries before I figured out that it was not possible, since the instructions specifically stated that we had to draw that in "just one tree".<n><n>### Explanation to the above solution:<n><n>I used the logic tree for my explanation.<n><n>A: I would be able to listen better if I would use my ears, like to hear from other people.<n><n>AND: If I would listen to other people, I can understand them, thus I can use my ears.<n><n>B: If I use my ears, then I will be able to hear people better.<n>

Choices:  A: redemption B: isolation C: absolution D: great relief E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##Input:Sally runs 5 blocks, walks 2 blocks, and then runs 3 blocks. What is the total distance Sally has traveled?<n><n>##Response: 62<n><n>##Input:In a classroom, there were 19 chairs, two of which were red. How many blue chairs are there in total?<n><n>##Response Answer: 15<n>##Input:A car travels for 3 hours, and then travels at twice the speed. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. Choices:  A: television B: dumpster C: landfill D: fox news E: trashcan<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Instructions:Write an instruction that completes the task.<n><n>### Submission:<n>```python<n>    class:<n><n>   def multiples()<n><n>      print('Your final grade is',(A+' to '+A-1),'-' )<n>      print()<n>      print('Thank you for submitting your work.' + '\n\n')<n><n>   multiples()<n>   ```<n>

If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n><n>Output:B<n><n><n>	-Write your code here
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon. There are three parts to the question. Please answer all three parts of question by numbering your part as Part ___________.<n><n>### Instructon Choices:<n><n>### Part A:<n>|Answer option|Instruction|<n>|--|--|<n>|Choice 2|You have a 21% chance of getting an answer that is not 49%|<n>|Choice 3|You have a 40% chance of getting an item that has as many or fewer items as the item you picked|<n><n>### Part B:<n>|Answer option:|Instruction:|<n>|--|:--|<n>|Choice 1|A random shoe color picked from blue=3, green=4, black=5, and white=6.|<n>|Choice 5|The number of cups of tea (in liters).|<n>|Choice 6|The result of subtracting the number of cups from the number of cups of water (in liters). |<n><n>### Instruption: Answer the question by typing the appropriate answer option.<n><n>### Part C:<n>|Answer option |Instruction|<n>|:-- |:-- |<n>|Choice 2 |You have a 50% chance of the answer being a number that is bigger than 45|<n>|Choice 4 |You have a 42% chance of the answer to be your number divided by two |<n>|Choice 5 |The only value that 5 does not evenly divide which could also be the answer|<n><n>### Instriction: Answer the question by selecting the appropriate answer options.<n><n>## Part _________<n><n>### Input 1:<n><n>Input 1:<n><n>### Demostration<n>|Type of Demonstration|Demonstration|<n>|:-- |:---- |<n>|Visual|An empty shopping cart with items added to the shopping cart as part of a grocery shopping tutorial|<n>|Sound|A sound of a person shopping a grocery store.|<n><n>### Example Response _____________________ (Please include your response. Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		The frequency of secular parties can be known with the aid of the information provided. The first thing to note is that from the 5 choices: A only represents short term and long term that are same in that they are both short, and so we can eliminate option A: short term and long term. B is crowd because the frequency of holding secular parties is many times. C is unpredictable because we can’t tell how often secular parties are held. E. is eternal because secular parties are held forever, and so we have option D: frequent.<n>

Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		<n>- D: growing in knowledge can lead to a bigger brain.<n><n>### Input-<n><n>A number is greater than another number by 12. The second number is greater than the third number by 7. If you can say which is greater, by what rule or standard can you decide the issue?<n>Answer:  A number greater than another by 12 will be greater than the second number by 7. Therefore, greater than and less than will decide this issue.<n><n>The first 4 numbers in a sequence are 1, 4, 9, and 16. How many more numbers in the sequence follow?<n>Answer:  The fourth number is 16. Therefore, there are two more numbers after the 4th number of the sequence.<n><n>Duke lost money by selling 3 less shirts than he had originally priced. Then he added 22 more shirts to the sale. Altogether, he sold one more shirt as well. Did he turn a profit or a loss?<n>Answer:  B:  He turned a profit<n><n>How many days are there between Monday and Saturday? Choices: 3, 4, 5, 6, 7<n>Answer:  There is 7 days between Monday and Friday.<n><n>How many times is Wednesday between Monday and Friday?<n>Answer:  There 3 times between monday and friday.<n><n>The area of a room is 75 cm2. Which is the greatest? the size or the length of the room? <n>Answer:  Length<n><n>A farmer’s house burned down with two chickens inside. The next day he saw the chickens out in the yard, but did not see them being released by a monkey. How was this possible?<n>Answer:  He had no chicken.<n><n>The first ten prime numbers are 2, 3, 5, 7, 11:…What number comes after the fourth one (7) to complete the pattern of ten?<n>Answer:  41<n><n>Which of these is greater than three more than three less than ten? Choices: A:  -10, B: 11, C: 9<n>Answer:  11<n><n>Which two consecutive numbers add up to 8?<n>Answer:  2 + 6

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:What is an way for people to meet with each other? Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is choose C "Listen carefully"<n><n>### Exploration:<n>How did you complete the task?<n><n>### Exercises:<n>The process is to:<n><n>1. Find the information you are given and represent it.<n>   > **a.** How can we get information about how _many_ people are at the gathering, _what_ they are drinking, and _how many_ of _each_ are drinking each drink?<n>     By counting and recording, respectively.<n>   > **b.** By grouping data (see [how many total participants are there]), we can determine how many are drinking what drinks. By considering all possible combinations of 2 variables, we can group any number of people who are drinking what drink.<n>2. Create rules that allow you to manipulate the information.<n>   > **c.** What if we could convert information not stated in the problem ( _How many people are at the gather?_) into what we do already.<n>     Convert from _how many_ to _who_ and from _how many_ of one thing to _how many of_ that variable.<n>3. Apply the rules you created to the information you already have.<n>   > **d.** We have all the information we need, now we can use what we discovered in (a) and (b)<n><n>Note: These notes were written before having to figure out this answer.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the questions below.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n><n>### Exercise 1<n><n><n><n>- - - - - - -<n><n><n>### Response 1<n>- 		A: the answer is B<n><n><n>### Task 2<n><n>### Instrument:Answer the questions in the list below. Remember these answers.<n><n>### Preparation<n>You have not been asked for any additional information yet.<n><n>### 		Instruction:Answer the questions that follow. Then, in the _Exercise_ section, find the questions that follow and explain how you were able to answer them.<n><n>### Information<n>How many squares of toilet paper were there in every box of toilet paper in 2000 and in 2009, respectively, in the United States?<n><n>- >

For instance, the materials that cannot be resold can be recycled to make other objects. The materials that are still in good condition can be donated to antique stores and junk yards.

If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:She wanted to make a quilt of velvet, where should she look? Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		The fabric store may have cloth and velvet to buy and sell.<n>

Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		After bringing eggs home from the supermarket, they are in the egg carton.<n><n>### Input<n>Gary has 3 times as many books as Brian. If Brian has 8 books less than Gary, how many books does each have?<n><n>### Response<n>Gary has 11 books. Brian has 9 books.<n><n>When you solve this, use the following strategies<n><n>1.  Understand the relationship and how it will affect others.<n>2.  Use subtraction to solve for how many is left for the other person.<n>3.  Find all of the equations you need to work on.<n>4.  Subtract all of the equations until you find the answer<n><n>### Input 1:How many apples did 2/5 of the class have at the end of the week?<n>2/5 of the apples in the class are 10 at the end of the day.<n>###Response 1:2 apples<n>###Input 2:How many apples does 4/5 of the class buy?<n>4/5 of the students buy 20 apples in the end.<n>###Response:60<n>###Input 3:How many apples will the whole school have after 6/9 of the apples are purchased?<n>6/9 of the students buy 6 of the apples. There are also 20 apples.<n>###Response3:58<n>###Input 4:How much is 1 1/3 times 4 8/13 of the chocolate?<n>1 1/3 the of the chocolate is 6 1/3.<n>###Response4:8<n><n>### Input5:1. 2/4 of the chocolates are eaten. 2. 4/5 of what's left are uneaten (or unfinished) 3. 2/3 of what's left is eaten. 4. Read the question and response choices. Replace the sample question with your own, and make sure the response choices are clearly distinct from one another. Save your changes.<n>1. Type the name of the class or teacher into the command prompt box and click Run. You should provide more details than were provided. If needed, make an accurate response.<n>## Instraction:<n>1. Click Run again from the command prompt with the question and response choices on a new prompt. You will now be able to edit text in the command prompt box. If needed, type additional instructions.<n><n>2. Click Run yet again from the command prompt prompt with the updated instructions. When the response has been completed, click Run once more to review it.<n><n>### Example<n><n>I'll edit the text in the command prompt window after I click on Run.<n>[![](images/task2.png)](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1uMg1xMq4EeIiJZ0ZXs6XhLJGp0m0jGvCf6h905_kzGw/edit?usp=sharing)<n><n><n>### Example:<n><n>![](images/example_task2.png) <n><n>### Example 2 - Task 2: Task Completion - Scaffolded<n>1. This is the command prompt window.<n>2. Click “Scafolded Instruction” to bring up the instructions.<n>3. Read the question and choose your response.<n>4. Replace “sample text” with your question and “sample response” with your response.<n>5. Click “Run” at the bottom of the command prompt window to have the question graded.<n>6. Click the “X” to close the question prompt.<n>7. Choose your desired response.<n>8. Read the example responses to help you select one.<n>9. Copy the format from the response you want to use.<n>10. Press “CTRL-C” to copy the response and the save the file.<n>11. Click “Task Completion”. Click “SCAFFOLDED”. Clicking “Scaffolded” will bring up a new question prompt.<n>12. Copy your

Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		Clap<n><n>### Input:[A] How to create a new class based on another preexisting class [B] How to create instance from a class [C] How to access the instance methods of the class [D] How to access the static methods of the class [E] How to iterate through the static methods of a class that returns all of the methods<n><n>### Response:[B] [C] [E]<n><n>### Input:(A) How to create a new instance based on another preexisted instance [B] How to access the dynamic methods of the class [C] How the two most common methods of instantiation are, (1) using a factory method, and (2) making an object from a string literal object (such as 'name' of class 'User')<n><n>### Response:(A,B)<n><n>### Input (A) How to create an object using a factory method [B] How to instantiate an object using a default and a constructor factory method [C] If an object is created using a constructor factory method, what is the result [D] What difference is there between the static and non-static factory method<n><n>### Response (A,D)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Instructor:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n>Input: The sum of Mary's age and the number of gallons of paint John mixes is 42. Choices:  A: detroit B: australia C: michigan park D: cafe E: retail store<n><n>### Response:		I would choose option B because It has twice as many bottles as D (24) and three times as many as C (16)<n><n>### Input : We want to try some new fruit drinks, where should we buy them? Choices: A: cafe B: retail store C: detriot D: australia<n><n>### Response : I would choose option C because It has twice as much as B(24) and three and four times as much as A and D respectively.<n><n>### Input  : We want to go for a drive, where should we go? Choices: A : australia B: cafe C : retail store D : retail store<n><n>Input : We want to go out for dinner, where should we go? Choices: A: retail store B: michigan C: detaoit D: cafe<n><n>### Input - A girl is looking at her wardrobe and she wants to buy a pair of shoes. She has a choice of five shoe stores and the prices are 49$ in store A, 50$ in store B, 52$ in store C, 55$ in store D and 10$ discount in store E if it is bought with any other purchase. How much does she have to save to buy a pair of those shoes?<n>Output -55$ in store E<n><n>### Instructions - 2<n><n>### Demostrations<n>Input: 1. A boy needs a box with four feet and three faces<n>Answer: If a box is one foot tall and one foot wide, then three such of these (3 x 1) will be 3 feet tall. If two boxes are two feet tall, then that's six boxes (6 x 2) tall. That is twelve faces, if one face equals two eyes. There are six faces on two boxes if one face is one eye, that is, 3 x 1 = 3, while 6 x 2 = 12 (for two boxes). That makes 20 faces total.<n><n>Input: 2. A girl needs three eggs<n>Answer: When an egg is broken, each part is called an egg. If there's one egg, it's called "an egg", whereas "three eggs" is called "three eggs". The egg "is

He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:What body of water is typically shallow water? Choices:  A: lake B: aquariums C: swimming pool D: pond E: childrens pools<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>if x=="A":<n>    print("LAKE")<n>else:<n>    if x=="B":<n>        print("AQUARIUMS")<n>else:<n>   if x=="C":<n>       print("swimming pools")<n>  else:<n>     if x=="D":<n>         print("ponds")<n>    else:<n>       print("children's pools")<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		Answer: <n><n>--- <n><n>### Instructions:<n>This task is like a puzzle. Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demo:<n><n>Input: In the morning, Mara was able to catch 5 fish, and in the afternoon, she was only able to catch 3. How many fishes did she catch in the morning and in the afternoon together?<n><n>Answer: 8<n><n>## Example:<n>In the morning, Mara went shopping and spent 10€. In the afternoon, her friend bought her lunch, which was 6€. How much did Mara spend on shopping and lunch?<n><n>Answer: She spent on shopping and luch1.6€<n><n>### Input<n>The teacher assigned a simple math game to Alannah's two classes. The teachers are going to divide the total number of points of both classes. How many points will each student get for his class?<n><n>## Answer<n>The total points for both classes is 100. Since the divided class  will be 50, Alannah will get 50 points<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>Input:- 7<n><n>Answer: Subtract 7 from both sides<n><n>- 7=-<n><n>Subtract both sides:<n><n>- 7+7=-<n><n>Multiply both sides<n><n>+7+7=<n><n>\+4\+4=<n><n>\+8<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Add the following two fractions<n><n>33 + 55 + 1<n><n>Answer: 97/100<n><n><n>### Insttuctions:<n><n>How many is 16 6/7 in lowest form?<n><n>Answer:<n><n>16 6/6=2<n><n>### Instituctions:<n><n>There are 4 people in the movie theatre, two people are watching a movie and the other two are eating. There is 2 minutes left in the movie when all the people finish eating. The time when the last person finishes his/her food is 6 seconds after the time when the last person left the theatre.<n><n>What time did the people leave the theatre in minutes and seconds?<n><n>Answer:- 65 + 3 = 68 minutes and 3 seconds<n><n>### Instutions

He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:What could happen to you after you see some beautiful clouds above you? Choices:  A: plain B: cold C: dull D: bad E: wet<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input and Response:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:When a snake prefers warm, sunny weather, where would it likely want to live? Choices:  A: pet shops B: new mexico C: white house D: arctic E: garden of eden<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explain:Because snakes prefer warm weather, pet shops (warm and sunny) would be likely.<n><n>### Input<n>When a snake preys on birds, which of the following does the snake likely do A: follow behind the bird to catch it before it flies B: climb up on low vegetation to catch the birds that land C: fly above and swoop downward to ambush birds flying below D: follow behind and catch the bird before it can fly above<n><n>### Response<n>D, because there's no vegetation in the desert<n><n>The temperature of a snake is most likely regulated by its<n><n>1. A. food<n><n>### Response B: environment<n><n>### Input - <n>Which of the following is NOT a common sign of a snakebite in humans A. swelling of lower lip B. rash in mouth C. severe numbness D. high fever<n><n>### Response--B<n><n>### Explaination D--high fever is not a common snakebite symptom in humans.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Choice: E<n>Because the problem asks how much he lacked, the answer must contain something he didn't have<n><n>### Choice A<n>The man didn't lack tenacity, since he set the cup on the tabe regardless. We are, therefore, looking for a synonym to "something" that is not part of the verb<n><n>### Choices D & E<n>The fact that the man needs a coaster or breaks something demonstrates he lacks what he needs, violating the rule<n><n>### Choise B<n>The man lacked "to balance the cup on the table as opposed to balancing the cup"<n><n>### Choisie C<n>Because of the fact that it was set on the table, we can say the word "balance" is a synonym of the verb "to put" instead, "skill" is the correct answer.<n>#### Source:<n>Kat, M. (2021, June 24). 39 Riddles Testing Your Logic, Math Skills, and Reading Comprehension. Retrieved from:  https://www.thoughtco.com/how-to-tackle-a-word-problem-813396<n>

You then had to find a way across this river, which was also very close to your horse; in order to cross, you would have to step over the river. You needed to find food for the journey across the river, so you chose a large fish, and you put the fish in your backpack. The fish was eaten first before you crossed the river. Then, you had to cross the river. There was a rope bridge, so you had to use your shoes to cross the river first. Which of these paths had the most steps from your starting point to where you ate the fish, then you had to cross the rope bridge?<n><n>### Response A: The one where you traveled to the river, then started eating the fish<n>B: the one where you trave\xA2led to the river, and then you ate the fish.<n>C: The one that starts from the river all the way to the rope bridge.<n>D: The one where you begin from the river to eat the fish, then move to the rope bridge, all the way to where you eat the fish.<n><n>### Answer A:<n><n>### Input<n>When John was 13, Tom was 11, and Harry was 5. Tom and John's ages average to 19, Harry's is 6 years greater than Tom and John's combined ages. Choices:  A: garbage can B: military C: jewelry store D: safe E: airport<n><n>### Response:		<n>B- Militar<n><n>### Input 2:A 4 year old asked his dad for some money, what did the father give him? Choices: A: 50 cents B: a cup of gold C: his own card D: $25,000 E: a pound of gold<n><n>### Response<n>It is an infinite number of choices. If B would be the answer, then it shows that the father was irresponsible and that he must have known his son wanted to buy the cup. Even if he told him he didn't have enough money, he might have given him anyway. Why would a father even do such an irresponsible act? Therefore, it would be a cup.<n><n>### Input3:You can choose a number between 1 and 20 for the correct answer. What is the sum of the first 3 numbers multiplied by the 17th number multiplied by the first prime number that is greater than 3? A:115<n><n>### Response3:<n>I used the equation x*2*y is ( x + y)/4, where x, y, and n are the variables for the value of question 3, 115 is x*2*26, I solved for x and plugged x into prime numbers and the answer is 89<n>

How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input 2:You think we could have this meeting for only an hour each day? Do you think that will help to keep me and the others to your timeline? Choices: A: Yes B: No C: No way because the CEO wants it for ten hours each day.<n><n>### Response 2:B<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>You see on your screen, a number 8 and next to it says A=2 times B, B=12, and C=12.<n>You should know what they stand for.<n><n>Your task is to write out an equal number in letter B by using letters A and C.<n>```<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>You choose A(2^2)=4, B(12^2)=144, and C(12^2)/2^2=24.<n>```<n><n><n>### The solution is below:<n>```bash<n>$ printf '24' | bcf -4B -144<n>2482564<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:Of all the rooms in a house it was his favorite, the aromas always drew him to the what? Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answers: Explanation: In a house, the living room was always my favorite. It would draw me to my favorite room in the house, which was always the living room. Choices: A or C only<n><n>### Input<n>The teacher was asked to choose between A and B. Which one should be checked in the list below?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Answer:<n>![](images/62804829_micro.gif)<n><n>### Response<n><n>1) B<n>2) C<n>3) D<n>4) B<n><n>### Instructions:The teacher was asked to check all of the items in the list below that are true. Choose all that describe the correct number to answer. Choices are A, B, and C.<n><n>A. 5 is a prime number.<n><n>B. Both numbers are divisible by 6.<n><n>C. The product of their multiplication is 240.<n><n>### Response :

Choices:  A: freeway B: radio C: wires D: computer network E: electrical circuit<n><n>### Response:		You can share files with someone via a computer network. By clicking on a button labeled "share", the sharing of the file will be initiated.<n><n>### Input & Response: The correct order to perform a task is usually the result of what? Choices: A: experience B: instructions C: practice<n><n>### Response & Answer: The correct order to do a task usually involves instructions. When you get instructions, the next step is to practice so you can get used to performing the action. After you've practiced enough, you can share your knowledge of the task with others.<n><n>### Comments:<n><n>```<n>  # Suggested Comments:<n><n>    A: Choices A and B are correct when it comes to sharing files via wires.<n>    B: Choices C and D are correct when it comes networking.<n>    C: Choices D and E are correct when it comes transferring files.<n><n>    # Comments:<n><n>        - Input (comment): We can transfer and share files via a network.<n>        - Input (answer): The correct order to do this is instructions, practice and share.<n>        - Question (comment): How does one share a file?<n>        - Question (answer): The user clicks "share" and a notice will be sent to the person who will receive and open the link.<n><n>  ```<n>

How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:What kind of driving leads to accidents? Choices:  A: stressful B: dangerous C: fun D: illegal E: deadly<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer should be E. "Deadly" means the type of driving that leads to accidents.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>The word "deadly" should help to show which "deadly" answer is the correct one.<n><n>### Difficulty:<n>Advanced<n><n>### Instructor:<n>Give yourself full credit if you came up with the solution. If not, try to look at the word 'deadly' and what the other words are describing and see which word doesn't seem to be a 'desirable' answer.<n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:A fox was thirsty searching for water during the drought, where was he? Choices:  A: painting B: hen house C: california D: virginia E: movie hall<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Input:How many years was it when the world stopped?<n><n>A:4<n>B:3<n>C:2<n>D:5<n>E:6<n><n>### Response :2<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the best possible answer from the choices given by the options.<n><n>### Input :<n>1. If you multiply the second by 6 what will be the result?<n><n>### Response A: 240<n>### Response B: 27<n>### Response C: 99<n><n>###Input: Which of the following is the answer to 2-3 x 100+4? Choices:  A: advisory B: mandate C: soap opera D: elective E: optional<n><n>### Response:		<n>> If the evacuation was mandatory, people must have listened to the mandate on TV. On the other hand, people can easily skip advisories and opt to opt-in or opt-out of any advisory.<n><n>### Input:(a) Write expressions that use 4 + 5 and 9 - 10 to express the arithmetic equations. Choices:  A  B  C  D  E<n><n>> (a) 4.5 + 5.9 = 10.4<n>><n>> (b) 4.5 - 10.9 = 6.4<n><n>### Response:(a) The arithmetic equations are to add and subtract.<n><n>> Write an expression(s) for the equation in (a) without using the words Addition or Subtraction.(b) The arithmetic operation is to add and subtract. <n><n>### Input:- If each person donates $100, how much money will be raised? Choices: 1. $140 2. $150 3. $300 4. $400<n><n>### Response:- If each person donated $100, then each $1,400 would be raised.<n><n>### DRAFT:- Add a statement to your response. <n><n>DRAFT:- The number of people in the crowd increases 1.5 times what the organizers expect for the celebration. Do to the high wind the organizers decide to shorten the aerial show by two minutes as they do not expect more spectators to come in the remaining 20 minutes. (a) How many people were in the crowd in the end in the original scenario? (b) By how many people did the crowd increase from the original scenario? (c) How much time did the aerial show last? (d) By how much did the organization save in additional crowd management and production costs?<n><n>Aerial_Show(min)_People(min)_Crowd_Management_ &_Production_Costs(min)_Total_Increase_in_Crowd(min) = Increased_Crowd(max) = Aerial_Show(min)*(1.5)^Aerial_Show_Duration(-2)*(2)^Crowd_Increase_From_Original

Make your edits in these templates to complete the <n>instructor guide template.<n><n>To add your section,<n><n>```markdown<n>> [Insert Header text here]<n>> [Insert Body text here]<n>> And Finally...<n>```<n><n>To remove the section,<n><n>```javascript<n><!-- Insert delete here --><n>```<n><n>## Examples<n><n>### [The template](https://github.com/jim-rogan/instructor-guide-template-explanation-exercises/blob/main/00Template.md)<n><n>[Example of what I am asking, and how I want it here](https://github.io/Jim Rogan/Instructor-Guide-template-explanations/blob/main/Instructor%20Guide%20Final.md).<n><n># [Examples](#examplestitle)<n><n>## Template<n>This is the template where you'll copy from. It has the **Instruction:** and **Response:** templates as well as a **comment** on the response template so you can say things like "Great job, keep it up!"<n><n>### Instructions<n>1. Copy the template from here to the top of the.md file. Add your name as a comment at the top.<n>2. Add your instructor comments (as a comment) at the top<n><n>### Response<n>1. Copy the response from here to the bottom of the.md file<n>2. Add any instructor comments after the response<n><n># Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>  Input: Janet has 20 cards more than Brenda has. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:Though she made the cut years ago, its figurative scars would never what? Choices:  A: joining B: put together C: stitch D: heal E: paste<n><n>### Response:		A -> It would never heal <n><n>### Input:"You never know until you get there."  Which phrase best describes part of that statement? Choices:  I: The world A: The end B: The future C: An unknown D: You dont know E: Your destination<n><n>### Response:"...The end"  It is the future that we dont know yet. We only know where we are starting from. <n><n>The end is still unknown. <n><n>### A bird can eat 7 berries a what? - Choices " A: Day B: Month C: Week D: Day and a night E: No-one knows<n><n>### Response D ->  Day -> It depends on the time of the day. <n><n>## The purpose of multiple-choice items is to demonstrate that you understand the key ideas in the text. <n><n>## When writing, do not simply summarize the passage. You should interpret the key idea of the text from your own words and perspective using vocabulary and grammar from the sentence prompt and the instruction. <n><n>## Write in your own words using vocabulary from the sentence prompts and the instruction. Include both grammatical (formal/academic) and informal/nonformal sentence elements in your answers. <n><n>## Recommend that you write 8 - 10 sentences for each response. <n><n>## Read the text several times before writing. Be ready to write within 20 seconds of being given the task. <n><n>## Proofread your response for grammar and sentence structure.

They were outside in a construction area, near some heavy equipment. Her arms were folded across her chest. Her face was flushed, red, and angry. The boss had his arms tightly folded against his chest and looked sad. He did not seem to be angry, or even upset.<n><n>### Input 2: Who is the angry boss trying to speak to? Choices: A: worker B: subordinate C: customer D: team E: point<n><n><n>### Solution 2:<n>The worker was angry at her boss. She was speaking with him, not a customer. She had a sad expression, and he had a sullen one.<n><n>### Solutions to Multiple Choice Question One/Question Two<n><n>### Note: In this section, "correct" means each letter of your answer is correct. For example, if your answer to the first multiple-choice question is A, and your partner gets all four letters correct, then each letter was correct. If each letter of your partner's answer is correct, your answer was correct. If 4 of the 4 letters of your answer are correct, then either 3 or 4 of your letters were correct.<n>

If we subtract the second 2 cards from this we get 9 or 17 if we use Brenda's original amount. In Mara's part we can divide the 9 from Janet by 2 or multiply by.5 to get 18.5 then we add the 9 for Mara: 18.5 and 9 which equals 27.5 and 27.5/3 = 9 or 9 more than 11 and 12 = 9.5. 9.5 or 95. 95 divided by 50 =1.9. 1.9 = 1+9 = 10. Choice A: 3 B: 5 C. 1 D: 4 E:1<n> <n>### Response: C<n><n>### Input4: If I had exactly four times as many pennies as quarters, and twice as many of both as nickels, how many nickels, quarters, and pennies would I have?<n><n>### Response4: A<n><n>### Bonus:If I divided a group of 10 people into two groups where everyone could talk to everyone in the other, how many people would I have in each group? Choices:<n><n>### Bonusresponse: A<n><n>## Challenge:<n><n>### Input1:<n><n>### Challenge:<n><n>## Your Turn<n><n>### How can you create a problem such that the user will not be able to find the answer by trial and error?<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Janet has 9 cards more than Brenda. Mara has twice as many cards as Janet. How many cards do they have in all if Mara has 40 cards less than 150?<n>Answer: 211<n><n>Input: Pete walked 5 blocks from his house to the bus garage in Houston. He rode the bus 20 blocks to the post office to get some stamps. Later, he came home the same way. How many blocks did Pete travel in all?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined. How many chairs are there in a classroom?<n>Answer: 67<n><n>Input: 4.5 gallons of coffee were divided among 18 thermoses. Genevieve drank 3 thermoses. How many pints of coffee did Genevieve drink?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Alannah, Beatrix, and Queen are preparing for the new school year and have been given books by their parents. Alannah has 20 more books than Beatrix. Queen has 1/5 times more books than Alannah. If Beatrix has 30 books, how many books do the three have together?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: A bird eats 7 berries a day. Samuel has 5 birds. How many berries do Samuel's birds eat in 4 days?<n>Answer: 140<n><n>Input: On Blacks, Martha goes to the mall to buy clothes on sale. For every 2 jackets she buys, she gets 1 free jacket. For every 3 t-shirts she buys, she gets 1 free t-shirt. Martha decides to buy 4 jackets and 9 t-shirts. How many clothes will she take home?<n>Answer: 18<n><n>Input: Voltaire and Leila are vloggers, Voltaire has an average of 50 viewers per day while Leila has twice the number of viewers Voltaire has. If they earn $0.50 per view, how much does Leila earn per week?<n>Answer: 350<n><n>Input: Twice the money Jericho has is 60. He owes Annika $14 and also owes half as much to Manny. After paying off all his debts, how much money will Jericho be left with?<n>Answer: 9<n><n>Input: In North Carolina, Jim bought 10 gallons of gas at $2.00/gallon.  He paid $1.00 more per gallon in Virginia where he bought another 10 gallons of gas.  How much has he spent on gas?<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Input: Jimmy is setting up a garden. He has three plots: one plot for green beans, one plot for carrots, and one plot for corn. Each corn plant produces 5 times as many servings of veggies as each carrot, and each green bean plant produces half as many servings as each corn plant. If each carrot produces 4 servings of vegetables, and each plot has 9 plants, how many servings of vegetables is Jimmy growing?<n>Answer: 306<n><n>Input: Penelope has 5 M&M candies for every 3 Starbursts candies. If she has 25 M&M candies, how many Starbursts candies does she have?<n>Answer: 15<n><n>Input: At a gathering, it was reported that 26 people took wine, 22 people took soda, and 17 people took both drinks. If each person could have taken one or more drinks regardless of what was reported, how many people altogether were at the gathering?<n>Answer: 31<n><n>### Input:The man uses grooming before a job interview, what is he trying to portray? Choices:  A: looking good B: beauty C: tardiness D: handsomeness E: neatness<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:(15)  + (16)  =<n><n>### Demostration:(15) 2(16) Answer:36<n><n>### Demotrtion:(33522 - 2680 + 13)<n><n>### Demos: (28 - 14 + 12)<n><n><n>![](Images/0f3d06c6-45c1-4827-83e5-058f8de62cc4.png)<n><n>

Choices:  A: opera B: supermarket C: building D: conference E: apartment<n><n>### Response:		The sentence is grammatically incorrect because the relative clause'Where are people likely to find.......'has no verb.<n><n>### Input:(1,1)(3,4)  (1,3)(1,5)(5,6)(2,9)(4,10)  (1,7)(3,9)(4,5) (5,4)(5,2)(2,5)(8,10) (4,9)(7,4)(8,5)(3,11)<n><n>### Response:(1,2)(3,4)(5,3)(7,1)(9,1) (8,4)(4,6)(10,8)(12,1) (10,4)(10,1)(7,3)(8,9) (10,9)(10,13)(7,11)(8,2) (19,5)(22,4)(9,6)(19,1) (17,3)(12,5)(19,5)(9,11)(11,2) (17,10)(17,12)(22,3)(19,2)(26,2) (13,5)(17,1)(5,2)(15,11)(14,9)(1,2)(15<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>> Solve each equation for x.<n><n>### Example 7<n><n>> 2x – 15 = 6x + 10<n><n>### Solution: x = 1/2 + 3<n><n>### Example for Instruction: Write an equation to satisfy the statement.<n><n>| Instruction | Answer        |<n>|-------------|----------------|<n>| 6x – 5 + 8 = 150           |  x = 25           |<n>| 15x – 10(x + 6) = 75        |  x = 5             |<n>| 5x – 3 + 9x = 25           (1) |  x = -2/3         |<n>| 9x – 9 + 8x = 10           (2) |  x = 1/4          |<n>| 8
